content: AUTHORITY TO PROVIDE PRIORITY HEALTH CARE TO VETERANS OF THE PERSIAN GULF WAR. Amendment to provide hospital care and nursing home care to veterans exposed to environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War. Amendment allows veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War to receive hospital and nursing home care for any disability, even without conclusive medical evidence of the association. Amendment expands outpatient care for veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War. Amendment expands outpatient care for veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War, specifically addressing disability cases before December 31, 1994, for veterans in the Southwest Asia theater of operations. The amendment expands outpatient care for veterans exposed to toxic substances during the Persian Gulf War in the Southwest Asia theater of operations. Medical services may not be provided for disabilities found to have resulted from causes other than the specified exposure. The amendments effective as of August 2, 1990, allow reimbursement for veterans who paid for hospital, nursing home, or outpatient services before the enactment date. Veterans who paid for hospital, nursing home, or outpatient services before the enactment date may be reimbursed for care related to exposure to toxic substances or environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War. The reimbursement amount will be the same as what the veteran paid for the services. The reimbursement for veterans who paid for care related to exposure to toxic substances or environmental hazards during the Persian Gulf War will be the same amount they paid for the services. Additionally, certain health care and other authorities are extended, including eligibility for care for exposure to dioxin or ionizing radiation and eligibility for sexual trauma counseling. The eligibility for sexual trauma counseling for women veterans is extended until December 31, 1994. Additionally, the authority to maintain a regional office in the Philippines is extended until the same date. The authority to maintain a regional office in the Philippines is extended until December 31, 1994, along with the advisory committee on education. SEC. 3. SHARING OF RESOURCES WITH STATE HOMES. The purpose of amending section 8151 of title 38, United States Code, is to improve care for veterans by allowing the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources. Additionally, the definition of "health-care resource" in section 8152 now includes hospital care, medical services, and rehabilitative services. The amendment allows the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share health-care resources, including hospital care, medical services, and rehabilitative services. The term "health-care resource" now encompasses various health-care services and support/administrative resources. The amendment allows the Secretary to make agreements with State veterans facilities to share specialized medical resources and health-care resources between Department health-care facilities and other institutions. The Secretary can enter agreements with State veterans facilities to share medical resources between Department health-care facilities and other institutions, such as research centers or medical schools. The agreements must either prevent duplication of resources or ensure that Department resources allocated for veterans' care are used effectively.
